messageBody:
We do this in Test Mentor's integration with JUnit by replacing the
junit.framework.Assert class with our own that redirects to Test Mentor's
mechanism for logging failures by creating/configuring results objects
instead of throwing exceptions. We then use a global preference to determine
whether to abort the test on any failure, which would be equivalent to what
JUnit does now, or to accumulate the results objects for later inspection.
Feel free to download and take a look at www.silvermark.com.

> Hi Juniters,

> I have seen several earlier posts here about having modified asserts
> that dont fail the tests altogether but simply collect the failures
> something like a check() condition which would then be used in the
> end in a final assert ... to fail or succeed a test? This would allow
> the testing to fall thru the code and the various assertions/check
> conditions!!
>
> But would love to hear / see whatz the cleanest meanest way of doing
> this?
>
> I thought of writing a overridden check() method for every kind of
> assert() in the api's
> this way we would have to call the check() instead of the assert,
>
> the check method then calls the assert with the same method argument
> in a try catch and in the try we set it to true
> and in the catch(AssertFailedException ae) we set the flag
> to "failed/false" whatever..
>
> Finally towards the end of the test we could then do a assert on the
> flag to fail or succeed the whole test??
>
> thoughts ideas welcome!!
